Subscribe We’re excited to introduce you to the always interesting and insightful Shanequa Lewis. We hope you’ll enjoy our conversation with Shanequa below. Shanequa , thanks for joining us, excited to have you contributing your stories and insights. Risk taking is something we’re really interested in and we’d love to hear the story of a risk you’ve taken. The most significant risk I took in starting my business was temporarily pausing my nursing career to fully explore entrepreneurship. It was a leap into the unknown, as I needed to determine if this path was truly what I wanted for the long haul. During the initial stages of my business, I still had to maintain a regular job to support my family as a single mom of three. I worked at Starbucks and also took on a full-time overnight position at a nursing rehab facility. Balancing these demanding roles while nurturing my business was no small feat. As the demand for my business grew, I realized I needed to dedicate more time to it. However, I wasn’t ready to leave my job entirely, so I transitioned from full-time work to a PRN/flexible schedule that allowed me to manage my time better. This decision came with the sacrifice of my benefits, but I was willing to take that risk to pursue my business goals. Building my business also meant spending less time with my kids and family. Thankfully, I had a strong support system in place, which helped me navigate this challenging yet rewarding journey. Every sacrifice I made was ultimately aimed at creating a better future for my family. Awesome – so before we get into the rest of our questions, can you briefly introduce yourself to our readers. As the owner of Smooth Tax Solutions LLC and Co-Founder of Mind Your Assets Tax School, I am excited to share some insights about my business and our upcoming launches. My firm is based in the heart of Birmingham, Alabama, I have been a part of the tax industry for a decade, transitioning to full-time entrepreneurship seven years ago. Alongside managing my businesses, I am also a proud mother of three.Smooth Tax Solutions LLC specializes in individual and small business taxes, offering a range of financial services tailored to meet the diverse needs of business owners. Our commitment is to provide clients with expert advice, professionalism, responsiveness, and most importantly, peace of mind when they trust us with their financial matters. Any insights you can share with us about how you built up your social media presence? Building my social media audience has been a journey rooted in consistency and understanding my followers. I make it a point to post regularly, which helps keep my audience engaged and aware of my brand. I focus on content that resonates with my audience, balancing humorous and relatable posts with straightforward business updates. This variety keeps things fresh and caters to different interests within my follower base. One key lesson I’ve learned is that followers can lose interest quickly. To combat this, I keep my captions concise and informative. Nowadays, people don’t want to read long paragraphs; they prefer quick bites of information that get straight to the point. Additionally, I believe in sharing glimpses of my personal life like celebrating my kids’ birthdays or sharing family vacations. This not only humanizes my brand but also helps my audience connect with me on a personal level, showing them that I’m just like them and not solely focused on business. Advice for Upcoming Entrepreneurs on Rising on Social Media: 1. **Stay Consistent:** Regular posting is vital. Create a content calendar to help you maintain a consistent flow of posts. 2. **Engage Authentically:** Don’t be afraid to show your personality. Share relatable moments from your life; it makes you more

approachable. 3. **Be Concise:** Short, impactful captions are key. Focus on delivering your message quickly to keep your audience’s attention. 4. **Utilize the Platform:** Social media is a free marketing tool. Leverage it to build your brand and connect with your audience until you can invest in paid advertising. 5. **Analyze and Adapt:** Pay attention to what types of posts get the most engagement. Use analytics to refine your strategy and cater to your audience’s preferences. Can you talk to us about how your side-hustle turned into something more. Becoming a business owner and a tax professional was never part of my original dreams or plans. My journey began when I was searching for a part-time job to support my family. I stumbled upon an opportunity for a tax professional position, and though I had no prior experience, the prospect of quick earnings and the chance to engage in something I thought I’d enjoy caught my attention. I decided to give it a try, and while the money did come in quickly, I quickly realized it came with significant responsibilities. However, I embraced the challenge. I found joy in the work and developed my skills over the three years I spent with the same company. Eventually, my passion for the field and desire for independence led me to establish my own firm, Smooth Tax Solutions. It’s been an incredible journey, transforming what started as a simple part-time job into a fulfilling career and business that allows me to help others navigate their financial landscapes. Photo credit: X @NydiaVelazquez During the early evening on February 23, P.S. 250 welcomed the community to enjoy performances and applaud area leaders as part of their Black History Month Celebration. Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso presents a citation of recognition to Shanequa Lewis, vice president of Borinquen Plaza Houses Tenant Association. Bianca Wheeler (chief of Diversity and Inclusion Office) accepts the honor for NYS Attorney General Letitia James, with NYS Assembly Member Maritza Davila Barbara Williams served as emcee. Bishop Dr. Michael Clarke (professor/director at Macedonia Theological Seminary and spiritual care giver at Brooklyn Family Justice Center) led the opening prayer. Theda Clay sang “Lift Every Voice and Sing” (The Black National Anthem). El Puente’s Crowd Control, Salvation Dance Company, and Brooklyn United Now lifted up the audience further with their music and dance performances. U.S. Representative Nydia Velázquez, NYS Senator Julia Salazar, NYS Assembly Members Maritza Davila (AD 53) and Stefani Zinerman (AD 56), Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso, and NYC Council Member Jennifer Gutiérrez presented commendations to those being recognized: NYS Attorney General Letitia James, Annette Spellen, Rashid Littlejohn, Dr. Robert Chin, Lohoma Shipman, Shonn Marrow, Tonya Lewis Taylor, and Shanequa Lewis. Mark Watson, MD accepts a commendation for Robert Chin, MD (NYC Health + Hospitals/Woodhull’s chief of emergency medicine) from NYS Assembly Member Maritza Davila Rashid Littlejohn of GCAMP (Genuinely Care About My Planet) speaks after being honored by NYS Senator Julia Salazar “I had the honor of recognizing Annette Spellen, who fought for years for women’s and racial equality in the NYPD and continues to make a difference as a member of Brooklyn CB 4 in Bushwick,” said U.S. Representative Nydia Velázquez. Spellen joined the New York Police Department in 1969. She worked undercover for three years, was promoted to detective, later was on the hostage negation team, and although she retired in 1993, she continued to volunteer for the NYPD. (l to r)Shonn Marrow (community liaison for The Wick Against Violence), Juan Ramos (executive director of Southside United HDFC—Los Sures), and NYC Council Member Jennifer Gutiérrez Rashid Littlejohn started GCAMP (Genuinely Care About My Planet) in 2008 in Bushwick. This initiative inspired the community’s youth to go green through educational workshops. In 2021 he launched Grants for Guns with St. Francis College, which offered young people who made the choice to turn away from violence the opportunity of higher education. NYS Senator Julia Salazar presented Littlejohn the recognition certificate. NYS Assembly Member Maritza Davila presented the honor bestowed on NYS Attorney General Letitia James. As James was unable to attend, Bianca Wheeler (chief of Diversity and Inclusion Office) accepted on her behalf. Davila also recognized Robert Chin, MD (NYC Health + Hospitals/Woodhull’s chief of emergency medicine), which was accepted by Mark Watson, MD also of Woodhull Hospital. (l to r)Lohoma Shipman (president, Bushwick Houses Tenant Association) and NYC Council Member Jennifer Gutiérrez Lohoma Shipman (president, Bushwick Houses Tenant Association) and Shonn Marrow (community liaison for The Wick Against Violence) were honored by NYC Council Member Jennifer Gutiérrez. NYS Assembly Member Stefani Zinerman honored Tonia Lewis Taylor (co-founder/ executive director of I Will Graduate). Shanequa Lewis, vice president of Borinquen Plaza Houses Tenant Association was honored by Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso. The school week following this celebration, P.S. 250 and M.S. 50 participated in Black Lives Matter in NYC Schools. A teach-in and art build occurred from 4 p.m.–6 p.m. on February 26 at M.S. 50, and during the same hours on February 29, P.S. 250 held a student showcase. (l to r)NYS Assembly Member Stefani Zinerman recognizes Tonia Lewis Taylor (co-founder/ executive director of I Will Graduate) Share this: Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Facebook Click to share on X (Opens in new window) X Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window) Email Like Loading... Posted in Community Action , Local Events Tagged Black History Month , Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso , Lohoma Shipman , New York
